results.title: Return to the dreaming (A)
results.creator_credit: Cecil Holmes, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian ark”.
Yirrawala, the great Aboriginal painter, takes his two sons who have grown up in the white man’s world back into Arnhem Land in an attempt to find the sacred caves and art galleries of his tribe. During the journey Yirrawala makes a bark painting in the traditional way and we see cave paintings never before recorded.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Cecil Holmes, Robert Raymond and Opus Films

group_siblings.title: The Coming of man
group_siblings.creator_credit: Vincent Serventy, Robert Raymond and Opus Films

results.title: The Coming of man
results.creator_credit: Vincent Serventy, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian ark”.
Aboriginal man is now known to have come to Australia at least 40,000 years ago, maybe even 50,000 years ago. Leading anthropologists, including Norman Tindale, John Mulvaney, Richard Wright and Bob Edwards explain their finds, including a 30,000 year old skull of a cremated woman at Lake Mungo, the Kow Swamp excavation of skeletons which resemble Java man, the 20,000 year old wall markings of the Koonalda Cave and the strange engraved stone faces of the Cleland Hills.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Vincent Serventy, Robert Raymond and Opus Films

results.title: The Cage (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Art of silence: pantomimes with Marcel Marceau and his partner Pierre Verry”.
Allegorical pantomime performed by Marcel Marceau showing a person struggling to escape from confinement- an enclosure of invisible walls. Marceau’s groping movements and final breakthrough, only to find another invisible wall, express mankind’s continuing struggle for enlightenment. Marceau believes that “we have but to walk out of the cage”. Also features his partner Pierre Verry. Suitable for upper secondary school level.

results.title: Bip as a soldier; The Hands; The Painter.
results.creator_credit: John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Art of silence: pantomimes with Marcel Marceau and his partner Pierre Verry”.
A compilation tape featuring Marcel Marceau, introducing the art of mime through the characater of Bip. “Bip as a soldier” shows the soldier as a tragic and heroic figure. “The Hands” is an allegory of the struggle between good and evil. The serious tone is lightened by the interpretation of “The Painter”.

results.title: Youth, maturity, old age and death
results.creator_credit: John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Art of silence: pantomimes with Marcel Marceau and his partner Pierre Verry”.
In four minutes, and not moving from one spot, Marceau expresses the seven-ages-of-humankind, beginning with life emerging from a mother’s womb, through the cycle of life, to the grave. Marceau believes “this pantomime reveals, maybe the best of what mime can do in condensing time.”
results.description:

results.title: The Dream. The Maskmaker. Youth, maturity, old age, death. The Sideshow.
results.creator_credit: John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Art of silence: pantomimes with Marcel Marceau and his partner Pierre Verry”.
Features Marcel Marceau. “The Dream” presents the idea of dreaming. The Maskmaker” shows the many faces of man. “Youth, Maturity, Old Age, Death symbolically presents the cycle of life beginning with life emerging from the womb through to the grave. “The Sideshow” is a pantomime of circus performers demonstrating their skills.
results.title_for_label: The Dream. The Maskmaker. Youth, maturity, old age, death. The Sideshow.

results.title: Bip at a society party; Bip hunts butterflies; The Cage
results.creator_credit: John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Art of silence: pantomimes with Marcel Marceau and his partner Pierre Verry”.
Marcel Marceau introduces the art of mime through the character of Bip. “Bip at a society party” portrays many amusing characters encountered at a party. “Bip hunts butterflies” is a tragic comic mime in which Bip discovers how fragile life can be. “The Cage” is an allegorical pantomime of a person struggling to escape from confinement.
results.title_for_label: Bip at a society party; Bip hunts butterflies; The Cage
